cleaned_text: Proponents of Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) have trusted its practice for over 2000 years. TCM has a rich history and continues to grow in popularity. The National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health offers great [insight](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/whatiscam/chinesemed.htm) on the beliefs that gave rise to TCM, the therapies and techniques in practice today, and the science that currently supports TCM. History asserts that TCM has its roots in ancient Taoism. Similar to Taoist beliefs, TCM sees humans as microcosms of the universe. Ancient TCM proponents also agreed with Taoist practitioners that balance was important. In TCM, the balance of opposing yin and yang forces supports holistic health. In addition to the Yin and Yan forces, TCM also believes in Qi as an energy that flows through every individual and is essential in maintaining health. TCM is based on the belief that fire, earth, wood, metal, and water have the ability to represent all manner of phenomena. TCM includes a variety of practices and treatment methods. Here are some of the most well-known: In 2012, data gathered from 29 [pain studies](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3658605/) showed that acupuncture patients reported better pain relief than the patients who did not receive acupuncture. Recent Tai Chi studies seem to support this therapy as beneficial in joint [strength and mobility](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/tai-chi-may-good-physical-therapy-arthritis-related-knee-pain-201606159780) as well as general wellbeing in certain populations.
